The Smel Thief 
 Joane Bloch (retold folktale) 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mr Shabangu was the best baker in town.
 
 Every morning he woke up at four o’clock
 to mix and knead the dough for his
 famous buns, cakes and biscuits.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 By eight o’clock the people of the town
 were walking past the bakery on their
 way to work and schol. By this time the
 
 cakes and buns were almost coked, and
 the most delicious smels wafted out of
 
 the bakery’s windows. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Many of the people went into the bakery
 to buy their breakfast. Mr Shabangu
 
 smiled hapily at them as he pased
 them the fresh, tasty cinamon buns and
 warm, golden biscuits that were so
 
 famous in the town. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But other people were not so lucky.
 
 Because they had so litle money, the
 porer people of the town could hardly
 
 ever aford to buy any of the delicious
 buns, cakes and biscuits. Al they could
 do was enjoy the lovely smels that
 
 drifted out of the bakery windows.
 When Mr Shabangu noticed these people
 
 snifing the air near his bakery, he said
 angrily, ‘How dare they snif my delicious
 smels!’ 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ‘Those are MY smels. I made them, so they belong to me! If people want to smel my wonderful smels,
 they should pay for them!’ He hufed and pufed and wiped the sweat from his brow, before turning back
 the oven to bake some bread and rols for his lunchtime customers. 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One old woman especialy loved the 
 smels that drifted out of the bakery 
 window every morning. This was Ma 
 
 Shange who slept on a bench in the park 
 every night. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A few weks before, a kind person had 
 given her the money to buy herself a 
 
 cinamon bun. She had taken the bun 
 back to the park and ate it very slowly, 
 licking her lips and sharing the last 
 
 crumbs with the birds. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 After that, although the old woman didn’t
 
 have enough money to buy breakfast,
 she longed for the delicious bun again.
 So every morning she walked slowly past
 
 Mr Shabangu’s bakery, snifing the air
 and smiling blisfuly at the mouth-
 
 watering smel. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Ma Shange’s new habit made the baker
 very angry. As each day went by, he grew
 
 angrier and angrier with her. 
 Finaly, one winter morning when he was
 in an especialy bad mod, he stormed
 
 out of his bakery and grabed the old
 woman by the arm. 
 ‘How dare you steal my smels!’ he
 
 shouted. ‘You’re nothing but a smel
 thief!’ He wiped his hands on an apron,
 
 then puled it of and threw it back into
 the bakery. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ‘This is the last day this cheky woman
 wil steal my smels!’ he shouted. And
 with these words, he draged Ma Shange
 
 of to the court to se judge Ngwenya.
 The judge was siting down at his huge,
 shiny desk when the angry baker 
 
 stormed in, draging the quivering and
 confused Ma Shange with him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ‘God morning,’ said the judge in his dep voice. 
 ‘Sir,’ said Mr Shabangu furiously, ‘I demand justice! I wish to lay a complaint against this woman. Every
 
 day for the last thre weks, she has walked past my bakery early in the morning when my delicious
 smels are at their best, and stolen them. I demand that she pays for those smels!’

 against this woman. Every day for the

 stolen them. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The judge scratched his big, bald head for a moment. Then he cleared his throat. ‘Fair enough,’ he said to
 the baker. ‘Justice wil be done.’ He turned to Ma Shange. ‘How much money do you have on you,
 Madam?' he asked. 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ‘Only two rands,’ stamered Ma Shange. 
 ‘Wel,’ said the judge, hand it to me, please.’ Mekly, Ma
 Shange reached into the pocket of her taty old cardigan and
 
 puled out two one rand coins. She handed them to the
 judge. He tok them, thanking her politely. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Then he shok the coins in his big fist, so that they made a
 clinking sound. ‘This is my judgement,’ he said to the baker.
 
 ‘The punishment must fit the crime. Therefore the sound of
 Ma Shange’s money is the payment you wil get for the
 smels she stole. And now I wish you a god day.’
 
 The baker loked thoughtful. Then, realising how
 unreasonable he had ben, he turned slowly and walked out
 
 of the rom. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The judge smiled kindly at Ma Shange, and handed her back 
 her money. 
 'Now, Madam, he said puling a brown paper bag from his 
 
 briefcase, would you care to join me for breakfast? These 
 buns are stil warm, I bought them only half an hour ago.’
